text.front:
International Journal of Modern Physics A
Vol. 28, No. 12 (2013) 1350041 (13 pages)
c
World Scientific Publishing Company
DOI: 10.1142/S0217751X13500413
SCATTERING STATES OF HULTH ÉN INTERACTION
IN MINIMAL LENGTH QUANTUM MECHANICS
H. HASSANABADI, * , ‡ S. ZARRINKAMAR † and E. MAGHSOODI *
* Department of Basic Sciences, Shahrood Branch,
Islamic Azad University, Shahrood, Iran
† Department of Basic Sciences, Garmsar Branch,
Islamic Azad University, Garmsar, Iran
‡ h.hasanabadi@shahroodut.ac.ir
Received 20 January 2013
Revised 13 March 2013
Accepted 18 March 2013
Published 3 May 2013
We first revisit the nonrelativistic minimal length quantum mechanics and reveal an
interesting symmetry of the problem. In fact, we will show that the cumbersome problem
can be cast into the ordinary Schrödinger equation with a new effective potential. Next,
as a typical example, we show the minimal length Schrödinger equation in the presence
of a nonminimal Hulthén vector interaction. The transmission and reflection coefficients
are reported as well.
Keywords: Generalized uncertainty principle; Hulthén potential; transmission and reflec-
tion coefficients.
PACS numbers: 03.65.−w, 04.60.−m, 42.50.Nn, 04.62.+v
text.body:
1. Introduction
Quantum gravity, quantum geometry, string theory, black hole physics and
doubly special relativity imply minimal length (ML) of order Planck length l P =
G/c 3 ≈ 10
−35 m.
1 Although the quantum effects are negligible in low ener-
gies, they do play a significant role in high energy physics which are comparable to
Planck mass
c/G ≈ 10
19 GeV/c
2 . The latter leads to a modification of the tradi-
tional Heisenberg uncertainty principle (which in fact allows for a zero minimum
length) into the form which we recognize as the generalized uncertainty principle
(GUP). On the other hand, deformation of the uncertainty principle corresponds to
a different Schrödinger equation different from the ordinary one. Therefore, when
text.note: ‡ Corresponding author.

Int. J. Mod. Phys. A 2013.28. Downloaded from www.worldscientific.com
by EUROPEAN ORGANIZATION FOR NUCLEAR RESEARCH (CERN) on 04/13/15. For personal use only.

May 3, 2013 9:19 WSPC/139-IJMPA
S0217751X13500413
H. Hassanabadi, S. Zarrinkamar & E. Maghsoodi
text.body:
our starting square, i.e. the wave equation, is altered, the physics of the prob-
lem does definitely change. As the field is much younger than its classical partner,
there are much fewer studies and challenging questions are yet unanswered. Some
interesting works in the field are as follows. Konishi et al. studied the ML and the
GUP in string theory.
1 Maggiore proposed a GUP in QG,
2 investigated its relation-
ship with quantum groups
3 and worked on the corresponding algebraic structure.
4
Garay discussed various points of QG under an ML.
5 Kempf et al. commented
on the Hilbert space representation of the GUP.
6 The hydrogen atom within this
framework was investigated in the work of Brau.
7 Scardigli searched the princi-
ple from the micro-black hole Gedanken experiment.
8 Ran and coworkers solved
the Coulomb problem in one dimension via the path integral approach.
9 Amelino-
Camelia, in an ingenius paper, proposed a testable scenario for the relativity with
ML.
10 Chang et al. exactly solved the harmonic oscillator problem in arbitrary
dimensions.
11 Scardigli and Casadio discussed the GUP in connection with the
extra dimensions and the holograph.
12 Magueijo and Smolin worked on the string
theories with deformed energy–momentum relations and studied the consequent
possible nontachyonic bosonic string.
13 The quantum uncertainty within the con-
text of doubly special relativity was the subject of the interesting work of Ref. 14
by Cortes and Gamboa. One-dimensional box and momentum space wave func-
tion for a free particle were studied by Nozari and Azizi.
15 Nouicer considered the
Pauli-Hamiltonian in the presence of an ML in Ref. 16. The big-bang singularity
in the framework of a GUP was the focus of the paper of Battisti and Montani.
17
Slawny calculated the position and length operators in the ML theory.
18 Fityo and
his colleagues discussed the WKB approximation in deformed space with ML and
minimal momentum.
19 Bambi and Urban considered Gedanken experiment for the
simultaneous measurement of the position and momentum of a particle in de Sitter
space–time with a GUP. Their study revealed that the considered GUP is directly
connected to the nonzero cosmological constant.
20 Das and Vagenas studied the
universality of the QG corrections
21 and the phenomenological implications of the
GUP.
22 In addition, they commented on the discreetness of space from GUP by
focusing on relativistic wave equations.
23 Hossain et al. provided the society with
a background independent GUP.
24 Bouaziz and Ferkous solved the problem of
hydrogen atom with an ML in momentum space.
25 Ali et al. proposed a new GUP
consistent with the string theory, black hole physics and doubly special relativity
theories.
26 Their proposed GUP modified the quantum mechanical Hamiltonians
and therefore the Lamb shift, Landau levels and the tunneling current. Here, we first
revisit the nonminimal quantum mechanics. More precisely speaking, in other pre-
viously published papers the authors were left with a six-order ordinary differential
equation which was too cumbersome to be simply solved via the common techniques
of mathematical physics. To get rid of such complexity, some authors ignore the six-
order derivative and they are therefore left with a fourth-order one which is of course
easier than the former. But, the story can be followed much simpler via the analyt-
ical techniques already known for decades if we change the space of the problem via

. Such a replacement leaves us with neither a six-order nor a
fourth-order differential equation. Rather, we are left with an ordinary differential
equation with a different effective potential. We next apply our idea to the Hulthén
potential
27 which is a successful phenomenological potential in atomic, molecular
and nuclear physics (see Refs. 28–30 and references therein).
2. The Generalized Uncertainty Principle
An immediate consequence of the ML is the GUP
1,15

1,15 At low
energies, i.e. energies much smaller than the Planck mass, the second term on the
right-hand side of the latter vanishes and we recover the well-known Heisenberg
uncertainty principle. The GUP of Eq. (1) corresponds to the generalized commu-
tation relation,
15

(2)
where x op = x and 0 ≤ β ≤ 1. The limits β → 0 and β → 1 respectively correspond
to the normal quantum mechanics and extreme quantum gravity. Equation (2) gives
the ML in this case as (∆x) min = 2l p
√
α.

x → −∞, where ψ inc and ψ ref , respectively, represent the incident and the reflected
waves. On the other side, as x → ∞ the wave function in Eq. (22) is ψ R = ψ trans
where ψ trans denotes the transmission wave function. These definitions give us the
reflection and transmission coefficients as

5. Bound-State Solutions
In this section, we investigate the bound-state solutions of the Hulthén potential
which implies the transformation V 0 → −V 0 . Equation (9) for x < 0 turns into

.
(47)
In Fig. 1, we have portrayed the behavior of the reflection and transmission coeffi-
cients versus E n for β = 0–0.05. As we expect, the relation R + T = 1 is satisfied.
Figures 2 and 3 show the dependence of the transmission and reflection coefficients
on E n for different values of β, respectively. Using Eqs. (46) and (47), we can obtain
the energy eigenvalues. Bearing in mind that acceptable energy range for bound-
state energies E n , i.e. −|V 0 | < E < 0, we have reported the bound-state energies
in Table 1.
6. Conclusion
Bearing in mind the successful predictions of the Hulthén potential in various physi-
cal fields, we considered the ML Schrödinger equation under this interaction and re-
ported exact analytical solutions of the problem via a different methodology which
transformed the Schrödinger equation due to ML into an ordinary Schrödinger
equation with a new effective potential. To provide a more applied basis for pos-
sible further studies, we calculated transmission and reflection parameters as well.
Our methodology can be extended to a large class of interactions.
